awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Photon-Enabled Atomic Drilling of Graphene for Supercapacitors
awd_abstract_narration:
Supercapacitors have emerged as next-generation high-performance power sources for portable devices used in a wide range of consumer, biomedical, healthcare, and military applications.  It remains a fundamental challenge in supercapacitor design to simultaneously achieve high energy and power densities with a long cycle life.  A porous graphene framework, consisting of a three-dimensional graphene structure containing nano-sized holes and micro-size pores, has emerged as a promising solution to address this challenge due to its superior electrochemical properties.  However, the existing methods for fabricating this graphene framework often rely on thermal chemical etching processes, which suffer from low efficiency and poor controllability due to complex experiments and poor thermal stability of etchants.  This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge for the development of a novel manufacturing strategy using photon-material interactions to realize porous graphene framework fabrication with a high efficiency. This research will have  significant broader impact because of the spillover into literally all economic sectors because of the potential transformative  performance improvement of supercapacitors.  This project also provides an integrated science and engineering training platform for graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students, with particular emphasis on promoting participation of women and underrepresented students in research.

The goal of this project is to establish a novel photon-enabled atomic drilling process to fabricate porous graphene frameworks toward supercapacitor applications. The photon-enabled atomic drilling approach utilizes photons from a nanosecond pulsed laser to initiate atomic drilling of nanoholes in the graphene basal planes for porous graphene framework fabrication with high efficiency and controllability.  The major research objective is to establish a fundamental understanding of mechanisms involved in the photon-enabled atomic drilling process responsible for the formation of porous graphene frameworks.  A computational model capable of predicting photon-enabled bond excitation and dissociation as affected by the laser processing parameters will be developed.  Microstructure characterization and electrochemical property testing will be conducted to establish the process-structure-property relationship.  This research contributes to advances in photon-based manufacturing technology development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project established a novel photon-enabled atomic drilling (PEAD) process to realize fabrication of holey-graphene frameworks (HGFs) toward supercapacitor applications with a simultaneous improvement of the energy storage capacitance and power delivery density.  A comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms involved in the PEAD process that could lead to fast, controlled manufacturing of HGFs with improved electrochemical properties is gained. Specifically, this project studied the mechanism of photon-graphene interactions in terms of photon absorption and subsequent photon-enabled chemical reactions, which lead to atomic drilling to form holey graphene, developed the PEAD process setup for HGF fabrication, and  revealed the process-structure-property relationship of PEAD-fabricated HGF for supercapacitor applications.

The major outcomes include: 1) density functional theory models demonstrated that the chemical reactions in PEAD process mainly involve the etching reaction between edge atoms surrounding vacancies on graphene basal plane and the chemical etchant molecules or radicals (H2O2 or OH-) (Image 1); 2) molecule dynamics simulation models demonstrated that the PEAD process can be controlled by adjusting the graphene vacancies, functional groups, and localized kinetic energy input (Image 2); 3) process study demonstrated that a partial reduction-oxidation-reduction mechanism can describe the overall atomic reactions in PEAD process (Image 3); 4) holey graphene flakes obtained with nanosized holes (several to tens of nanometers, controlled by PEAD conditions) on graphene basal plane for various electrochemical applications (Image 4); 5) electrochemical testing demonstrated that the PEAD manufactured HGFs construct three-dimensional ion transport channels in the electrodes, thus improve the supercapacitor capacity up to 40% more than graphene, achieving exceptional energy density of 51 Wh/kg at a power density of 655 W/kg (Image 5).

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2023
Modified by: Qiong Nian

    Qiong Nian

(d) the number of the carbon atoms in graphitic rings changing with respect to the simulation time. (e) holey graphene obtained without pre-existing defects; (f) with pre-existing defects.
    Qiong Nian

(c) Gravimetric specific capacitance versus current density. (d) Ragone plots of HGF-based supercapacitor in comparison with commercial devices.

por.por_txt_cntn:
This project established a novel photon-enabled atomic drilling (PEAD) process to realize fabrication of holey-graphene frameworks (HGFs) toward supercapacitor applications with a simultaneous improvement of the energy storage capacitance and power delivery density.  A comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms involved in the PEAD process that could lead to fast, controlled manufacturing of HGFs with improved electrochemical properties is gained.
